dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK TREE LIMBS spread against a less-black sky. The STA beyond are vast and dim. BATS dip and wheel chaotically. can hear their wings: a desperate-sounding chk chk chk. RUTH KIMKE (38) stares up at them, very still, very uneas She has a watchful, owlish vibe. She’s slightly wall-eyed Her hair is long and plain and she appears fearfully hypnotized by the bats. Or maybe it’s the stars. She tips a BEER up, nearly kills it without blinking. WIDER, we see her yard: a weedy little square enclosed by tall rickety fence. MUSIC and VOICES drift faintly from elsewhere, some other yard. Somebody SHRIEKS in delight. Ruth looks in that direction, all alone back here. She glances down at her hand...which is SHAKING. Then back to the dark sky as an OMINOUS TONE sounds and w CUT TO BLACK. TELEVISED IMAGES fill the screen, pixelated and washed-ou with SOFT HAPPY ELEVATOR MUSIC eating all the sound: A huge TRASH ISLAND bobs in the ocean. SOLDIERS fire mach guns in the Middle East. A WHITE COP clubs a BLACK KID.

dialogues.text: I remember you, Ms. Kimke, what can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I was just calling to follow up on...I was curious if there were any...”suspects” or whatever yet.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: Suspects?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: The matter at my house yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, I understand what you meant, I'm--just a minute-- There’s a MUFFLED CONVERSATION, he’s distracted.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, it's very...Look, I assure you we're going to take every uh...all possible avenues.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I thought maybe if you came back in daylight and looked around a little closer you could-- An aggravated SIGH blows through the line...

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: Could I put you on hold a moment?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Sure.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 19. The HOLD MUSIC comes back on and she listens to it a bit...until it stops. Silence. RUTH (CONT’D) Hello? VERY CLOSE ON HER by now, looking down at the dead phone. can see her jaw muscles clenching. Her wheels turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth walks to the center of the yard to look at the BACK from a distance. Contemplates it. She goes to the SIDE GATE, which leads back here from the front. Looks closely. The LATCH is rusted shut. She tries it but, no, it’s stuc She scans the yard. Walks along the FENCE LINE, scanning. At the REAR FENCE, she stops suddenly. Looking at-- A CERTAIN SPOT where a patch of honeysuckle is ripped loo She touches it, dangling there, the flowers still fresh. She looks straight down and sees something that freezes h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth’s FINGERS clamp the top of the fence and then, with GRUNT of effort, her HEAD appears, peeking over to see... A LOOSE BOARD has been propped against the fence on this side. Like a ramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops back down to her side again, looking down at-- THE FOOTPRINT she noticed in the soft earth right there. She stares at it like it’s a snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth moves purposefully along, scanning the shelves of-- VARIOUS CRAFT SUPPLIES, clay, paper mache, plaster strips  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth and a SULLEN TEENAGER get there at the same moment, Ruth defers, ‘After you’, holding a PACKAGE OF PLASTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth whisks WHITE POWDER and WATER in a bowl. Wk!wk!wk!wk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIQUID PLASTER is poured into the FOOTPRINT. Ruth waits. Bugs BUZZ. She bites a nail. Glances at the s tentatively, like she might see something terrible there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less-than-impressed, Ruth looks down at-- THE PLASTER FOOTPRINT MOLD she’s made: terribly misshapen crusted with dirt. Looks like a burnt jellyfish. But looking closer she discerns A FLAT STRIPE ACROSS THE SOLE, the tread pattern interrupted for two inches. Weird And its unusual LIGHTNING BOLT LOGO is visible in relief. EXT. RUTH’S HOUSE - DAY Ruth comes outside, WALKS RIGHT INTO CAMERA, Cape Fear-st looks up and down the block... ...and EXITS FRAME as that same SOUL BOOGIE kicks back in LOUD. (We can call it RUTH’S ACTION THEME from now on.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING BESIDE RUTH, propelled by HER THEME though this LOWER MIDDLE CLASS NEIGHBORHOOD: small houses in need of paint, chain link fences, old trucks. She turns up to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nok-nok! AN OLD MAN sucking on a squeeze yogurt appears behind the screen door, squinting out at her.  21.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to bother you, sir. I’m your neighbor over there. My house was robbed yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Sonsabitches.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was sometime between nine and six thirty, I don’t suppose you saw anything?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Well, I’11 tell you something... But instead he just takes a long slurp of his yogurt, kin loses his thought. She waits patiently.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: (‘this?’) It’s just regular yogurt you can sip on. (SLURRP!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .--hey, fuck it...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What did you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Oh. It’s all going to hell. Ruth smiles tightly in thanks and heads off. OLD MAN (0.S.) (CONT’D) You know that, dontcha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it’s a YOUNG MOTHER with her BABY on her hip.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 22.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MOTHER
dialogues.text: I don’t know nothing about no robbery.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Maybe you saw a strange car. Or someone acting furtive.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MOTHER
dialogues.text: Furtive?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Sneaky.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MOTHER
dialogues.text: I know what furtive is. I’m sorry that happened but I don’t know anything to tell you. Ruth nods, disappointed, and looks at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What’s her name?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MOTHER
dialogues.text: Khaleesi.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (tired but genuine) That’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it’s a GEARHEAD with CAR PARTS and TRASH strewn about yard, wiping his hands and wolfishly looking her up and d

dialogues.speaker: GEARHEAD
dialogues.text: Suspicious?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Or just, like, out of place.

dialogues.speaker: GEARHEAD
dialogues.text: Oh, for sure. Just this mornin’ a Dominican fella came ‘round with a tree saw and a push mower. Told’m, ‘I can take care my own lawn, thanks, but good try.’ He knew to keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I bet.  23.

dialogues.speaker: GEARHEAD
dialogues.text: You could gimme your number. If I thinka something.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (turning to leave) You won’t. But her ACTION THEME is sounding echoey and distant by no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth rounds the corner, uncertainly. Unfamiliar territory

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses the jungle yard, comes up the porch, nok-noks the door. There’s no answer but... .+.-she can hear SHREDDING HAIR METAL wafting from the ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes around the side of the house, where the METAL i louder and tied to savage CARDIO EXHALATIONS...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One--get some! Two--get some! Three- -get some! Unh! Four--get some! IN THE OUT-OF-FOCUS FOREGROUND we discern SOMEONE on a WE BENCH, rhythmically lifting the PRESS BAR as--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Excuse me? TIGHT ON THE LIFTER’S HAND, as the exhalations stop, reac for his, no, not his NUNCHUCKS there, for his TOWEL... ..-which he wipes his sweaty face with as he sits up. Loo who it is: the Dog Man himself, who is in fact named TONY Mutual recognition. A charged and awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You said ‘fine.’  24.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The implication being--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nevermind. She turns away but he stops the MUSIC--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, wait up... --and approaches, showing his palms. Ultra sincere, this

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. That's not me. Leaving a B.M. in your yard? That’s not who I am. I...I was embarrassed. Sometimes I’m just so into my thoughts, you know? Like, deep. And I won’t even notice what Brian's doing. He tips his head towards the WINDOW, where the DOG who mu be named Brian is watching them, calmly panting.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (turning to go) Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You can hit me.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (stopping) What? No.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: One strike. To balance the energy between us. I won’t defend myself.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t like hitting people.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m a very physical person. That’s just how I experience the world. Action, reaction. Cause, consequence. Pain isn’t real. A brief beat and she starts to leave again but--

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why are you here? She stops again, shrugs in defeat.  25.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: My house got robbed. Tony’s face clouds over.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Did you call the authorities?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah, they...I dunno. It didn’t seem like they could do very much. So I was just asking around, if anyone saw anyone. He seethes in place and then, all at once...

dialogues.speaker: HE GRABS HIS NUNCHUCKS AND--KASH
dialogues.text: Ruth JUMPS and Brian starts BARKING furiously in the wind

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (Chinese for “quiet”) An jing! An jing! (and to Ruth now) That makes me furious.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Y-yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What kind of person does that?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What’d they take?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: My computer. My grandma's silver-- KASH! HE SMASHES AGAIN, RE-INFURIATED.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (retreating) Sorry I bothered you.  26.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You didn’t bother me, this affects all of us--BRIAN. STOP IT. But Brian is only BARKING louder as Ruth scoots away...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Okay. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can I do anything?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nah, uh, I’m good, thanks... She slinks away around the house and Tony watches her go. INT. FRONT ROOM - RUTH’S HOUSE - NIGHT A MELANCHOLY COUNTRY TUNE plays. A BEER sweats on a coast Ruth sits curled on the couch, reading her NOVEL. She tur page but...lets it close. Staring off, disinterested. As if as an afterthought, she brings out-- HER PHONE, on which she taps a CERTAIN APP: Loc8. She log but gets a PROCESS WHEEL turning, endlessly. ‘Searching.. So she tosses the phone aside in disgust. She rises. Sips. Paces a slow circle...which becomes sway to the MUSIC. Like dancing. A private, lonesome moment. B-Bing! She looks to HER PHONE, which is suddenly glowing She picks it up, stares at the screen, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Holy shit. ON HER PHONE, a RED DOT blinks on a MAP SCREEN. ‘Device Online’, it says, ‘129 Grove St.’ HER POLICE REPORT, with Bendix’s card, is snatched--ssk! She hurriedly dials a number but--

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX VOICEMAIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You've reached Detective Bendix with the Robbery Fraud. I'm not available now but if you'1ll--  27. She disconnects, blinking, and quickly dials another numb

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Police non-emergency.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Hello. Yes. Okay. It’s--my case number is zero-zero-zero--

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just a second, ma'am, what's the--?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No, it’s--I can see right where it is. My computer was stolen and I can see it.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR
dialogues.text: So it's not stolen?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No, it’s still stolen, my phone is saying where it is, I have the address, someone needs to go there before it turns off again and--

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR
dialogues.text: We can include that information in the report but we can't send units out at this time. Would you like to-

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Wait--what? Why?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR
dialogues.text: They need a search warrant in order to--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: But you don’t have to search, it’s right there, I know where it is!

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR
dialogues.text: We cannot send units at this time.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OPERATOR
dialogues.text: We can include that information in the report file--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disconnects in unhinged frustration. (Remember how Jennifer Grey hung up the phone in Ferris Bueller? Yeah.) She thinks, frantic...until something new occurs to her. Struggling to calm herself a degree or two, she dials aga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON DAN, wincing at the caller ID but answering anyw

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hey, uh, Angie’s closing tonight.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh, actually, I was kinda wondering what you were up to?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Me...? He’s crouched next to Jana, who’s in the tub, her entire covered in shaving cream: two little eyes in a blob of fo

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Doin’ my own time, you know, not the institution’s. What’s up? But she has second thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s...eh, you know what, it’s nothing. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. Sorry. Click. Dan looks at his phone, unsure, as the Jana-Blob l at him and, b-blub, a tiny fart bubble breaks her bath wa END INTERCUT. CLOSE ON RUTH, breathing faster as the COUNTRY MUSIC morp into her ACTION THEME which carries over to...  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM THE STREET SIGN, ‘Grove Street’, WE TILT DOWN as RUT CAR pulls up with its running lights on. She double-checks HER PHONE, her face eerily green in the screen’s glow, and looks across at-- 129 GROVE STREET, a trashed-out party hovel at the end of GRAVEL DRIVE. YOUNG FOLKS milling in the dark yard. RAP fuzzes from inside, people HOOT and CACKLE down there. RUTH glances up and down THIS BLOCK of dark shabby houses craggy low-hanging trees, deep shadows. Spooky, all of it She swallows, returns her attention to-- 129 GROVE, where a GIRL now clumsily TWERKS in the yard a SEVERAL BOYS film her with their phones, itching themselv On Ruth. Hmm. 129 GROVE, where one of the BOYS is now doing PUSH UPS wi ANOTHER GIRL balanced on his back, sloshing her drink.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (distantly) Wooooc0e! On Ruth. Hmm. 129 GROVE, where A BOY is arranging a WATERMELON before ANOTHER BOY who is spraying a AEROSOL into a “POTATO GUN” homemade contraption of PVC PIPE.) On Ruth, Hmmm, just opening her door when--

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: On Ruth, HOLY SHIT, slamming the door and SPEEDING AWAY. EXT. TONY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Tony opens the door. Ruth looks wild-eyed. Fast dialogue-

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I need back-up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (zero hesitation) Okay.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 30.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You got those ninja sticks?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nunchaku is an Okinawan weapon--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Fine--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: “Ninjas”, as you call them, are--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Right, okay--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I got something better.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Fine. I just--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do you know what a morning star is?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I just-- no, I--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Lights out.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I just need you to ride with me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Right on.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m Tony.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Coooool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH’S CAR pulls up again: Tony is driving now (with Bria panting in the back), Ruth sits shotgun, pointing--  31.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: There. 129 GROVE, where the party appears to have moved inside. lone longhair SMOKER lingers by the front door. Tony nods, all business, but then...bows his head, steepl his hands under his chin, WHISPERS to himself. Ruth watches in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DRIVEWAY, Ruth and Tony walk towards us: kunch kun kunch on the gravel. He carries a MORNING STAR FLAIL and BELT BUCKLE contains a THROWING STAR. She looks profoundly anxious as--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Were you praying?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You asked for help. I asked for help. That’s how things get done. (with a sidelong smirk) Don’t worry...I’m not gonna let anything happen to you. TRACKING WITH THEM as they approach the HOUSE. Up ahead, SMOKER sees them coming, takes a wary drag. They arrive. A long beat of nobody knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: My computer is inside this house.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER
dialogues.text: Say what? She shows him her PHONE with the blinking LOCATION APP bu

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what the fuck that is.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t want trouble. My computer was stolen, this says it’s in there, I just want it back. No questions. Can you please get it?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER
dialogues.text: I can get deez nuts.  32.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (perfectly confused) You can get these nuts?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay, tough guy, you had your chance-- And then this all happens very fast:

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER
dialogues.text: Guh!

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh God are you--? Smoker staggers inside--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where, blinded, he TRIPS and FALLS into a COFFEE TABLE- KRASH!--totally SHATTERING IT. As Smoker lays GROANING on the floor, Ruth and Tony (with morning star again) come boiling in behind him to see-- THREE KIDS (20s) watching FUNNY INJURY VIDEOS on a LAPTOP all of them suddenly frozen and flabbergasted. A charged beat, everyone coiled and staring at each other Smoker lies MOANING and BLOODY on the floor. ONE KID (the one doing push ups before) starts to rise--

dialogues.speaker: PUSH UPS
dialogues.text: What’d you do to Keith? BUT TONY HURLS HIS THROWING STAR--CHNK!--INTO THE WALL. (Admittedly, many, many feet away from the kids.) PUSH UPS (CONT’D) Dude!  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 33. Tony then brings out an M-80 FIRECRACKER, LIGHTS IT, TOSS IT DOWN THE HALL (so everyone has to wait an awkward few seconds until) K-BAM! PUSH UPS (CONT’D) RUTH DUDE! STOP! (to Tony, ‘stand down’) It's okay. But now the GIRLS are rising in anger (the one who was twerking and the one who was going ‘Wooo!')-- wooo GIRL TWERKER This is totally Both you ugly motherfuckers inappropriate, come in here better drag your shit on like this--violence is not outta here ‘fore I get my power, you know, it’s, like, keys out n’ fuck you both th the absence of-- fuck up--

dialogues.speaker: SHUT UP
dialogues.text: She doesn’t merely SCREAM this, she fucking ERUPTS: her w soul vents out. It’s like an E.M.P., everything stops. In the ringing silence, she raises her PHONE like a pisto slowly, deliberately, and aims it at that laptop... The Kids blink, still paralyzed by her sonic boom. She taps her LOCATION APP and... B-bing! The LAPTOP chimes in response. B-bing! B-bing! At that, Push Ups and the Girls seem to wilt. Busted. Tony shakes his head in disgust. Gotcha. Ruth extends her arm, eyes locked on Push Ups, and as one final YOUTUBE BIKE HORN sounds, she closes the LAPTOP. With ceremonial solemnity, she starts to pull it away but RUTH (CONT’D) The power cord, please. And so Woo Girl bends down to unplug it, hand her the COR Ruth stares at them, sadly. They can barely meet her gaze  34. RUTH (CONT’D) It doesn’t feel good when people you don’t know come into your house, does it? (beat) Where’s the silver and the medicine? But Push Ups is genuinely confused...

dialogues.speaker: PUSH UPS
dialogues.text: Uh. There’s some TheraFlu in there but no silver. And I didn’t steal that, miss. Cost me good money.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PUSH UPS
dialogues.text: I bought it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Bought it where?

dialogues.speaker: PUSH UPS
dialogues.text: Killer Sills.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: PUSH UPS
dialogues.text: Consignment place out the way. Sells everything, real cheap. wooo GIRL (helpfully) She got her first communion bracelet there. Twerker holds up her braceleted wrist in confirmation. Ru processes all this, darkly.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They got silverware there? They shrug. I dunno, maybe. RUTH (CONT’D) Write it down.

dialogues.speaker: PUSH UPS
dialogues.text: Want me to drop a pin or--?  35.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No, man. On paper. Shame-faced, Push Ups scribbles on a NAPKIN and hands it Ruth. She pockets it and, with a final glare, turns to go Tony pries his THROWING STAR from the wall. He has to rea wiggle it. Takes a while. He finally gets it out and--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's how hard I threw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH’S ACTION THEME BLASTS, subsuming all sound as RUTH A TONY STRIDE AWAY IN SLOW MOTION. Her eyes glitter, gulping deep giddy breaths. Weightless. He looks like a kid on Christmas who just got the best to Nothing else matters. They share a_look. UP AHEAD, Brian barks noiselessly at them from the back o HER CAR, like he’s cheering racers to a finish line. INT. FRONT ROOM - RUTH’S HOUSE - NIGHT NORMAL SOUND & MOTION ABRUPTLY RESUME with some CELEBRATO CAJUN blasting (gotta be “Hot Chili Mama” by Beausoleil) RUTH DANCES an exuberant victory dance with a pint of Bea one hand: part End Zone shuffle, part go-go shimmy. She’s exactly graceful but her whole heart is in it. Yesss! TONY DANCES with all the rhythm of a motor throwing a pis He takes a sip of booze, winces, not a big drinker. Brian paces happily between them. From across the room, Ruth smiles at Tony. He smiles back SLOWLY PULLING BACK FROM THEM until... THE FRONT TABLE enters frame, on which that PLASTER FOOTP MOLD is resting, its LIGHTNING BOLT LOGO plainly visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A RAGGEDY SNEAKER with that very SAME LOGO. And, might notice, a STRIP OF DUCT TAPE wrapped around it. Tha flat stripe on the plaster mold.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 36. PULLING OUT FROM IT as POP MUSIC hums through walls, gradually revealing SOMEONE on the toilet... Except, oh dear, they’re actually atop the FLUSH TANK, th TRACK PANTS down around their ankles: a dreaded Upper Tan His name is CHRISTIAN (20): raver threads, chopped peroxi hair, andro-model looks with hateful ice-chip eyes. Someone outside TAPS tentatively on the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Just a sec! He wipes, pulls up his pants, replaces the TANK LID. He r the faucet (without washing) and rummages through-- A JEWELRY BOX, pocketing VALUABLE ITEMS: rings, a necklac He cuts the faucet. Grins at himself. A crazed vampire gr INT. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY —- MCMANSION - SAME Christian emerges wearing his “normal person smile” but t YUPPIE WIFE waiting there is still startled--

dialogues.speaker: YUPPIE WIFE
dialogues.text: The guest bathroom is downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: It was an emergency. Perturbed, she glances into the bathroom as-- WE TRACK WITH CHRISTIAN, strolling away, cool as a cucumb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE TRACK CHRISTIAN downstairs into MUSIC and PARTY CHATTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SUBURBAN CROWD with their cocktails and parenting stori Christian cuts through them like a panther through geese. He’s moving towards the FRONT DOOR but... AHEAD THROUGH THE CROWD, he sees Yuppie Wife pointing him to her HUSBAND, who’s coming this way so--  37. Christian does a mellow about-face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian rolls out from under the propped-open GARAGE DO and trots away until-- The HUSBAND steps out to block his path, “friendly”.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Hey there.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: (instantly “in character”) Oh hey, buddy!

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: You're a guest of Miranda’s, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: Right. John. You guys have a beautiful home.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Thanks, we try. Remind me again, where do you know Miranda from?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: Ah, from work. She’s been a great mentor, I’m learning so much. Husband drops the act, coldly brings out his PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: YUPPIE HUSBAND
dialogues.text: I want you to stand right there, I’m going to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: Aw, c’mon, man... Christian suddenly notices someone over Husband’s shoulde CHRISTIAN (CONT’D) Oh, good, there you are! So Husband looks back but, oops, made ya look-- CHRISTIAN LEAPS AT HIM LIKE A FERAL ANIMAL. Husband tries defend himself but it’s too late, he goes down thrashing.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian walks briskly down the block, out of breath. Hi shirt has a little bit of blood on it. He glances back at the DISTANT VOICES back there...

dialogues.speaker: VOICES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Call 911! .+.-and sprints onward to the VAN parked in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE VAN pulls in, the lights cut off. Christian hops out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SILHOUETTE of Christian drifts towards us, pausing no listen, head cocked like a bird.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: Marshall? A SHIMMERING FEMALE FACE glows out of the blackness, brie illuminated by her cigarette cherry. Her name is DEZ (20s hippie-child wraith with strange serpentine eyes. She gestures c’mon and melts away in a swirl of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dez leads Christian over a ridge to a LOW CLEARING where. A MAN-SHAPE is hunched beside a small CAMPFIRE. Sucking a THIN GLASS PIPE, setting it down with a euphoric exhale. He runs a comb through his greasy hair. Homemade CAT TATT on his hands. This is MARSHALL (50s): maybe a hobo, maybe ghoul in his ratty car coat and shredded cowboy boots. Dez stretches out on her sleeping bag, watching as... Marshall pats the ground beside him. Christian sits and brings out the STOLEN ITEMS, offers them to Marshall who holds them in the firelight for inspection. He is pleased

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Now we're cooking with gas.  39. And Christian, in turn, is pleased. He’s a good puppy. In fact, Marshall literally scratches him under the chin. PUSHING IN ON MARSHALL as he smiles his yellow teeth at D PUSHING IN ON DEZ as she blows smoke, gives him a kissy f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CEILING FAN whirs. Ruth rises into frame: peering dow through her red-eyed hangover at-- Tony, dead asleep on the couch, drooling freely. Snrr. She drops back out of frame again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth and Tony quietly eat pancakes. Occasional furtive glances at each other. Forks clink on plates. Brian pants on the floor, looking from one to the other. After a bit, Ruth digs into her pocket, brings out that NAPKIN, stares at it a moment...and slides it across. Slowly chewing, Tony stares at it. SIUS, reads the scribble, RR2 BOX49. He lifts his eyes to hers. He nods one time. She nods bac EXT. KILLER SILLS’ PLACE - DAY ON A RURAL ROUTE MAILBOX, ‘19 - SILLS Salvage Consignment which we PAN OFF OF as RUTH’S CAR pulls into this DUSTY L parks next to an EMPTY SPOT. Ruth and Tony get out, glance about, and we TRACK WITH TH past ROWS OF TABLES stacked with all manner of SECOND-HAN JUNK. Hot sun and dust, FLIES buzzing steadily over it al A handful of SHOPPERS, poor folks with sunburns, quietly through old baby clothes and used sewing machines. The nexus of it all is a corroded BARN, its high doors opening into a cave of blackness. As they drift that way.  40.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (hushed) Maybe we should hold hands. (off her ‘huh?’ look) Like we’re engaged. So, hand in hand now, they approach the BARN. She notes: THE WEIRD SYMBOLS, burned into the transom: porcupine log and Evil Eyes and Masonic pyramids. A FADED ‘TRUTHER’ POSTER: the burning WIC and ‘Do the Mat A DISUSED CAROUSEL HORSE leaning against the barn. NOTA R HORSE, the hand-scrawled sign informs us. INT. BARN - KILLER SILLS’ PLACE - SAME As they enter the dim interior, a motion sensor BINGS! KILLER SILLS (80s) lifts his black pebble eyes from the KEYBOARD he’s repairing. A Santa’s Elf gone to seed, he l permanently startled under his Nick Nolte mugshot hair. FROM ABOVE, Ruth and Tony approach, rows of HIGH SHELVES either side, full of STUFF like the end of Raiders. TRACKING WITH THEM, scanning the inventory. BIRDS flutter the rafters. A RACCOON crawls in a corner. Ruth swallows as they near him, puts on an anxious smile. Tony catches this, gives HER HAND a reassuring squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, sir, uh--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: You like music?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Mm, sure, everyone likes--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: (showing the keyboard) Five preset tones, 9.38 killa-hertz sample rate with three unique demo modes: ‘Calypso’, ‘Disco Dance’, and ‘Rock n’ Roll’, here...  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 41.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, wow, it’s great but-- We don’t really need-- He hits demo for some 8-BIT CALYPSO with intense eye cont

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, thank you--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: And. He hits demo again, for some FUNKY DISCO, more eye contac

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, really, thank you, but--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: Annnd. But this time it’s a BLAND 4/4 BEAT and Tony’s kinda into

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: We were really wondering if you had any antique silver service. Sills looks at her. Blinks wetly. Reaches one finger out tap the keyboard and stop ‘THE ROCK’. It’s suddenly very quiet. Ruth shifts uncomfortably under Sills’ wounded stare. As he strains up out of his chair--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: (sadly, quietly) If you don’t like music you can just say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sills morosely leads them to shelves of SILVERWARE SET

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Are your ah, your newer items in any particular area?

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: They're antiques.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I just meant--  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 42. BING! There’s another customer, so Sills shuffles away. Alone now, Ruth searches a shelf and Tony searches anothe the VOICES of Sills and his customer drift indistinctly O But then the VOICES AND ALL SOUND DISSOLVE INTO DREAMY SC as Ruth’s eyes lock on something and she comes towards us There. A plain polished WOODEN BOX with a plain brass MONOGRAM: ‘SK.’ She lifts the lid, the silver inside glea Seeing this, her eyes water a little bit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDMA SALLY, a wee sweet old lady in a haze of warm sunlight, chuckles with her Virginia Slim 100 and iced te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NORMAL SOUND RESUMES as Ruth looks down at HER HAND, whic shaking, so she makes a fist. Whispering to Tony--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (re: the monogram ‘Sally. Kimke.' (then, with resolve) Go start the car. Excited and terrified, Tony nods himself into action. INT. BARN —- SAME Tony walks quickly towards the exit: trying so hard to lo casual that he appears to have a board up his ass. OUT OF FOCUS BEHIND HIM, Sills dickers with a Customer.

dialogues.speaker: SILLS
dialogues.text: Two hundred for these. Final.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: They were my Mom's.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 43.

dialogues.speaker: SILLS
dialogues.text: So take ‘e m to a regulated outfit. (beat) Mmhm. What I thought. EXT. KILLER SILLS’ PLACE - SAME Tony stiff-walks to RUTH'S CAR and as he slips in-- We see that empty spot is now filled with CHRISTIAN’S VAN INT. RUTH’S CAR - SAME In his nerves, Tony grinds the starter, VRR! He glances o to see MARSHALL watching him from the VAN’S PASSENGER WIN Tony smiles. Marshall smiles back, poisonously, with Dez behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a breath for courage, Ruth gathers the SILVER SET in arms and WE LEAD HER OUT OF THE AISLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING HER as she heads towards the entrance but--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sure are unloading yourself, last few days.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're moving away, So...

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh huh. “Moving.” She slows, staring in confused recognition at-- CHRISTIAN’S SNEAKER that now fills the foreground of this SHOT: the LIGHTNING BOLT LOGO, the DUCT TAPE wrapping it. On Ruth, stunned as she realizes it: that’s her thief. AT THE REGISTER, with the JEWELRY on the counter between them, Sills passes Christian some CASH and he quickly spl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. KILLER SILLS’ PLACE - SAME Christian hustles out, counting the bills as he moves. Ruth follows, hugging the SILVER SET, hypnotized by him. INT. RUTH’S CAR - SAME Tony twists in his seat to see her trailing slowly along-

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon, c'mon... EXT. KILLER SILLS’ PLACE - SAME TRACKING RUTH through the tables, Christian angling away her, towards the VAN when--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold on there... She looks back to see Sills coming after her, pointing. INT. RUTH’S CAR - SAME Through the back window, Tony watches Sills approaching R

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, no... --and now notices Christian hopping into the VAN’S DRIVER SEAT, Marshall giving him an oily salute as they BACK OUT EXT. KILLER SILLS’ PLACE - SAME Seeing the VAN start to pull away--

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: --she breaks into a TROT, still hugging the silver set. And seeing this, Sills now RUNS after her.

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: OH NO YOU DON’T! SHOPPERS watch idly as the hobbity old man scrabbles afte the young woman awkwardly jogging away with the wooden bo  45. KILLER SILLS (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No! Sills swoops in, CLUTCHES HER ELBOW--

dialogues.speaker: SILLS IN THE FACE WITH THE BOX. SILVERWARE FLIES LOOSE.
dialogues.text: He staggers, stunned, BLOOD in his mouth. Wide-eyed SHOPPERS saw this happen: oh shit, she's evil. Ruth sways, aghast: what have I done? RUTH (CONT’D) Oh...no...I didn’t.... Sills turns his face up to her and we see it change, fill with RAGE of his own, and he LASHES at her like a viper--

dialogues.speaker: YOU HIT ME
dialogues.text: Awkward and instantaneous, SHE THROWS UP ONE ARM TO WARD

dialogues.speaker: OFF BUT HE GETS HOLD OF HER MIDDLE FINGER AND--SNAP
dialogues.text: They break apart and the color drains from Ruth’s face as

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Guh. Tight on Killer Sills, livid--

dialogues.speaker: KILLER SILLS
dialogues.text: Now look what you made me do-- THUP! TONY’S FOOT IMPACTS THE SIDE OF HIS FACE AND SILLS DROPS LIKE A SACK OF WET LAUNDRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony hurriedly tosses whatever SILVER he can back into th box, quaking with giddy adrenaline over what he just did. Sills is out cold, mouth agape, SNORING as FLIES buzz him Ruth is hunched over, clammy-grey, gazing miserably out a THE VAN DISAPPEARING AROUND A DISTANT CURVE IN THE ROAD. As Tony helps her to her feet--

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was a side kick. A few Shoppers are stealing shit now and running away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON RUTH’S HAND as a splint is applied to her finger CLOSE ON THE DOCTOR, focusing on his work for a bit. Then

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The uh...that mail slot, huh? CLOSE ON TONY, observing from the sidelines, tight-lipped CLOSE ON RUTH, looking sad and exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Must’ve really slammed it hard. Her lip quivers, almost crying but not. Softly...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Slammed the shit outta it. CLOSE ON A BOX OF ‘PERCODAN’ being opened. Rip! CLOSE ON RUTH’S HAND, two FAT PILLS dropped into the palm CLOSE ON RUTH’S MOUTH as she gulps ‘em and chugs water. G INT. RUTH’S CAR (MOVING) - DAY Tony drives. Ruth stares out like a zombie, high as fuck, troubled. Some CHEERFUL POP NUMBER plays softly on the ra  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 47.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: See...you pivot on the ball of your foot and snap your hips out at the same time. That transmits a huge amount of power outward through the leg. It’s devastating when deployed correctly. Doesn't seem like she heard him. He lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That guy mighta killed me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Him? Nah. He’s scrappy, I’1l give him that, but he let emotions cloud his flow. Amateur stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No. He wanted to hurt me. I saw his eyes...after I hit him. He can see that pains her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey. You didn’t do anything wrong. That’s your silver.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Your superpower is certainty. He’s flattered but she doesn’t notice, she’s spiraling. RUTH (CONT’D) What if he had a gun? Or a knife? He mighta killed you, too. He... (beat) I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sorry? I should be thanking you. For the first time here, she looks at him. Huh?

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t uh...I don’t really have too many friends. I’ve been told I’m obnoxious? Which is...anyways. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 48.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My life is... (a little shrug) But today I felt electric. She nods blearily. It makes a weird kind of sense.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I wasn’t scared. I mean, I was...but it had no weight. And I am always scared. She turns her gaze back out the window again... RUTH'S POV, sliding by PILES OF GARBAGE, by HUNCHED PEDESTRIANS, by NEON-LIT SHOPFRONTS. Blurring decay. Her voice seems to come from elsewhere. Lost. RUTH (CONT’D) What are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Umm. Whatever you want? I mean, I gotta take Brian for a walk but--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What are we doing here. The world. He thinks a moment, but he knows this one.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Trying to be good. Or be better.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Quantify that shit.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I mean, y’know...values and whatnot.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That’s not a real thing. That’s a poster with a kitten on it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It is a real thing.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What about me? Am I good?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course you are.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 49.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I clubbed an old man.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Well, yeah--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: In the face.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: With a big wooden box.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Right, but in combat situations--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: There’s no upside. We come from stars, you know. He looks at her: what's this gibberish?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The upside is that nothing ends. There’s always time. You continue.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (“obviously”) Somewhere better.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: “Heaven?”

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m not saying clouds and harps and stuff...but there is more. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: How do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I just know it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (very quiet) I don’t wanna die.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 50.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You won’t. She grimaces at that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nnnot....right now?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s just gonna be black.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. It won't.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yes, Tony. It will. Just... (snaps her fingers) Like when you switch off a T.V.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But...that’s so hopeless. She shrugs. He considers her, vexed. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I show you something?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Mhmm...show me. As the radio fades into a JOHN HUGHES-Y LOVE SONG (“Bring The Dancing Horses” by Echo & The Bunnymen is perfect) he head lolls back in a druggy stupor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth drifts towards us down the aisle, eyes drawn upwards awe as THE SONG SUBSUMES ALL SOUND. A MURAL OF “HEAVEN” spreads before her: it’s a community project, so Jesus and all the happy folks with Him in the green sunny field resemble grinning misshapen cavemen. But, gazing up at it, she begins to smile. WIDER NOW, Ruth and Tony in a pew. Fluorescent banks and ceilings: a small, new construction church, FULL OF PEOPL The MINISTER reads his sermon. We can’t hear him but his language suggests a calm, grandfatherly warmth. PUSHING IN on Ruth, hearing his words, smiling dreamily.  51. CLOSER ON THE MINSTER as his “words” fall into sync with chorus of THE SONG. He's not performing it, he's just rea his regular sermon, but his lips subtly form the lyrics. Next to Ruth, Tony glances over at her sidelong. Taking i the curve of her cheek, the line of her neck. THEIR HANDS are resting on the pew, close together. He mo his PINKY, ever so slightly, so that it brushes hers. She looks at him. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SONG CONTINUES over this LONG SHOT in which Ruth and head away from us in the fading light, taking Brian out f walk. (And Tony has a plastic bag at the ready, btw.) INT. FRONT ROOM - TONY’S HOUSE - SUNSET THE SONG CONTINUES as we find Ruth and Tony sitting on hi sheet-covered couch in the stream of gold-orange light through the window. Brian is curled up nearby. SLOWLY PUSHING IN ON THEM, side by side, not talking, not moving...until she tilts her head to rest it on his shoul FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEAVY ROCK on the radio (“Forever My Queen”, Pentagram!) MARSHALL nervously counts the CASH for maybe the tenth ti HEADLIGHTS play on his face and he looks up. Christian gobbles some of RUTH’S MEDS and looks up. Dez was dozing but now she looks up, too.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: Finally. THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD, they watch a HEAVY PICKUP TRUCK g into this crowded PARKING LOT like a great white shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall, affecting a careless swagger, leads them along. Christian is tense. Only Dez is genuinely relaxed.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 52. The lot is clogged with NOISY BIKERS and ROUGH CHARACTERS hanging around the seedy BAR that throbs in the backgroun AHEAD, oozing from his PICKUP to greet some PALS, is the and only DONKEY DICK (40s). Corpulent redneck supreme. Marshall (and crew) arrives at the outskirts of Donkey Di jocular group and LAUGHS along with a joke he didn’t hear Donkey Dick regards them with open contempt.

dialogues.speaker: DONKEY DICK
dialogues.text: Not gonna waste my time again, are ya?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Nope. We’re whole.

dialogues.speaker: DONKEY DICK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Butthole, maybe. That gets big laughs. DONKEY DICK (CONT’D) Y'all been sleeping in that van?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (wanted to make a smart remark but) N-no.

dialogues.speaker: DONKEY DICK
dialogues.text: Cause one a you three stinks. Ain't quite fish but it ain’t quite chicken, neither, so I’m at a loss. More big laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It’s pork chops: we just dropped your Mom off. Yikes. No overt laughs. (But someone does snicker quietly Donkey Dick sizzles, infuriated. Marshall holds his ground. Christian swells his chest. De looks like she’s watching a mildly diverting sitcom. As Donkey Dick opens the LOCK BOX in his pickup bed and y out a PAPER GROCERY BAG--

dialogues.speaker: DONKEY DICK
dialogues.text: C’mon, ya fuckin’ comedian.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: vUMP! The van door slides open and Donkey Dick sets the P BAG inside with a clink! A semi-private staging area. Christian and Dez are hanging back, but they crane to see As Marshall opens the bag, practically salivating. It’s TWO HANDGUNS (a 4-INCH .38 REVOLVER & a .45 AUTO) an SAWED-OFF DOUBLE-BARREL SHOTGUN. Loose SHELLS in Ziploc b Marshall works the action on the shotgun, klik! k-klak! I kind of rusty and banged up, not the cleanest weapon.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Action’s a little janky.

dialogues.speaker: DONKEY DICK
dialogues.text: Gonna do brain surgery with it? Get whatcha pay for n’ you could barely pay for this. Donkey Dick swats him and Marshall hands over the CASH. As Donkey Dick counts it, Marshall gives a satisfied nod Dez and Christian and slides the bag out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (turning to Donkey Dick) Very happy that we could finally--

dialogues.speaker: HIS DENTURES POP OUT AS HE FALLS.
dialogues.text: Christian steps forward but Dez subtly blocks him: don’t. Donkey Dick pockets the money, shakes his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: DONKEY DICK
dialogues.text: Bring my Mom into it. The kids wait until he’s stomped off before... Dez scoops Marshall’s DENTURES out of the dirt, reaches i the van for a bottle of Pepsi to rinse them off. Christian helps Marshall stand. He can’t help but look diminished, accepting his teeth and slipping them back in But he rallies, a brittle little smile, a hoarse chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Eggs and omelets, like they say.  54. INT. FRONT ROOM - TONY’S HOUSE - DAWN Ruth stirs out of a deep, sweaty, painkiller sleep on the couch. Her first movements bring a GASP of pain. She remembers her BROKEN FINGER, winces at it. Then at... The plate of AMERICAN CHEESE SLICES (wrapped) and a SODA that Tony put out for her. A faint smile at that. But next to it is her SILVER SET, badly scratched, some b utensils sticking out. And her expression hardens.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How's the finger? WIDER, Tony’s shirtless in the kitchen doorway with a bow CEREAL, sweaty from a workout. Ruth stares at her silver.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (almost to herself) Fuckers got away.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but...you got it all back, right?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They were inside my house.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (philosophical shrug) So give the cops the tag number. Doubt they can do anything...but you never know.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (clenched teeth) I didn’t get the tag number.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (mouth full of cereal) Oh, I did. She swivels slowly to face him. He chomps, open faced.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Didn't I say that? INT. TONY’S BEDROOM - DAY HIS COMPUTER is clicked on. Bzzt!  55. SCREEN GLOW REVEALS BRIAN, panting happily in the darknes TONY SPINS in his chair to face us, bathed in SCREEN GLOW

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s all just ones and zeroes. Binary data connected by threads, like a web.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s...called the Web. She glances around the DIM MESSY ROOM: dirty socks, micro popcorn, a samurai sword. Heavy CURTAINS keeping the sun

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (like he didn’t hear her) Just gotta know how to dodge the spiders. He TYPES, hard and fast, “The Master Hacker” apparently.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You’re so sly, but so ami... ON SCREEN, a waterfall of PORNO POP-UPS. Amateur Slutz!,

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hastily rebooting it) Oops. SECONDS LATER, he’s TYPING hard again, totally focused.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Open sesame... ON SCREEN, it’s just GOOGLE: “look up a license plate?”

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Need a credit card. SECONDS LATER, Ruth's reading her VISA as he TYPES along-

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Eight. Four. Six. Nine. Five. Zero. Zero. Zero. One.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: And the expiration?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Eleven, nineteen.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 56.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: cvc code? SECONDS LATER, he clicks! the mouse and they both lean in

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Gotcha. ON SCREEN, a results page for WWW.TagSearch.COM, which re

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (like spitting out acid) Christian Rumack. INT. BENDIX’S CUBICLE - POLICE STATION - DAY Ruth sits anxiously, watching Detective Bendix gloomily p at her PLASTER FOOT MOLD with his pen. Eventually...

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: What do you do, Miss Kimke?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m a nursing assistant.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: Do you enjoy it? Her answer takes a moment to bloom, unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: Mm. Suppose I came to where you do that, your hospital--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s a post-op facility.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: Okay, suppose I came there and said, you know, maybe not that medicine, Ruth, maybe this one instead, dontcha think?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That’s not what I--  57.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: You present a certainty that the owner of a vehicle you happened to see at a garage sale is the same individual--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: His footprint--

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: --who burglarized your home and his foot, according to this, is made out of scrambled eggs. You tell me this with a straight face, the suggestion being that I am incompetent at my job.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No! No, sir, that’s not what I meant, I-I-I’d recovered my computer and--

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: I understand the chain of events as you tell them. Did it occur to you that the people who had your computer in the first place were the ones who broke into your house?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah but--

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: Occam’s Razor and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah but--what?

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: Did it occur to you that approaching a criminal suspect without official capacity is a good way to get your wig knocked off? What happened to your finger? (off her non-response) Were you engaged in a confrontation?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (re: her broken finger) It was an accident.  58.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: Have you been able to replace your medications?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (frosting over at that) Oh. I see. He pushes the plaster mold back towards her. Scraaaape. S stares at him a long, helpless beat. RUTH (CONT’D) Why don’t you want to help me? Isn't that your job?

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: (swelling with fury) My job? I am doing my job. You are not a professional. You are an interferer. You think because you leave your door wide open for some punk to stroll on in that the whole universe somehow now revolves around you? Grow up. We had a man beaten unconscious in his driveway last night by a total stranger and now he has skull splinters in his brain. The world is bigger than your silverware. People are experiencing bigger problems, people are--I’m being divorced, did you know that? Did you even bother to... He looks away, one hand over his mouth, SNUFFLES pitifull Some NEARBY COPS exchange a look: Ugh, this shit again.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: [Snnf.] Embarrassed and unsure what to do, Ruth glances around... then reaches out to put her hand on his-- But he yanks back as if scalded. Glaring at her, he wipes nose. Makes some notes, clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go home, Miss Kimke. She slides the REGISTRATION PRINTOUT towards him, tapping where it says ‘Rumack’--  59.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: But...this is the guy-- He snatches it, balls it up, tosses it.

dialogues.speaker: BENDIX
dialogues.text: No. It isn’t. And if you engage in vigilante action or mess around with this any further I won’t hesitate to have you clapped up. Follow me? She smolders. INT. RUTH’S CAR - POLICE STATION PARKING LOT - DAY Tony waits at the wheel, watching as-- Ruth comes stomping back with her plaster mold, gets in, SLAMS the door. He can see she’s furious, gives it a mome

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Now what? As she turns to him, unblinking, HER ACTION THEME kicks i turbocharged with additional frenzied percussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That same SLOPPY MAN is here again and, again, he drops a of chips, and again Ruth snatches it up for him but now--

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Pick up your shit. And then she grabs a BOX OF KIDS CEREAL: ‘Free Inside! JU G-MAN BADGE!’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth and a GUY arrive simultaneously but Ruth does not de

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Excuse me. EXT. RUTH’S CAR - GROCERY PARKING LOT - DAY FROM THE DRIVER'S SEAT, Tony watches uncertainly as...  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 60. Ruth DUMPS all of the cereal out, spilling it crazily, an then pawing inside the box for-- THE CHEAP CHROME “POLICE” BADGE she was promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH RUTH’S CAR, plowing steadily ahead as HER ACTION THEME crescendos and then-- INT. RUTH’S CAR - LAKE CIRCLE - DAY --it cuts. Ruth and Tony, parked, both staring out at--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Musta robbed a ton of houses. THE RUMACK MANSION, across the road, set back into the tr a secluded cabin palace. A few LUXURY CARS...but no van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING THEM as they near the house, Ruth taking note of THE MENAGERIE OF RATTAN ANIMALS, crafty if ostentatious l decorations: an elephant, a tiger, and a giraffe. Passing them, she hears a faint, ghostly RAWWWR: the thro rumble of a jungle cat. She double-takes the TIGER: the f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nok-nok! MEREDITH RUMACK (40) opens with a klieg-light sm Nails, hair, makeup: all perfect but age is closing in.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Yes? Ruth flashes her BADGE, Tony looming behind her in aviato

dialogues.speaker: RUTH TONY
dialogues.text: Good morning, ma’‘am, I was-- POLICE. Meredith blinks, still smiling, and Ruth resets. Ahem.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Could we have a moment of your time, please?  61. INT. MAIN ROOM —- RUMACK MANSION - DAY Meredith leads them into the expansive, immaculate home, genuinely delighted to have visitors, relentlessly cheerf

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Y'all care for some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH TONY
dialogues.text: No, thank you-- Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No trouble, I just press a button on the machine--boop! It’ll do a cappuccino, too, it’s like A.I.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH TONY
dialogues.text: In that case... Do you have cashew milk?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet I can find something! Meredith breezes off, leaving them in this vast show of wealth. Tony lingers over a PHOTO of Meredith, beauty pag winner, ages ago. Ruth gazes at ANOTHER PHOTO, A TAN BLOND MAN in pastel ra leathers, posing himself before some outre CONCEPT CAR.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I need to talk with Christian Rumack. Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Meredith works the fancy COFFEE MACHINE...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Well, he’s stilll out. Y'know, with his “friends.” I expect him back who knows when. Talk about what?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Choices he made. .-.-she adds a few fingers of SHERRY to her own cup.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I oughta make sandwiches, then. That could take all day.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Meredith sets out the COFFEE TRAY for everyone...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Do you know Christian's whereabouts the day of--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (sipping his cappuccino) A machine did this?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Huh. I worked at a Borders.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: The bookstore?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes, but they had a cafe, too. I got pretty good with the steamer. Could do smiley faces, winking faces, uh, peace symbols, hearts...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oak leaves. Just takes practice.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Would you happen to know Christian’s whereabouts the day before yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I'd barely know his whereabouts any day. He comes and goes, y’know? Ruth glances around, vaguely confused.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: But...he does have a job?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Some’d argue that’s all he has.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What’s he do? Meredith looks at Ruth over the rim of her cup. Gulp, gul  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 63.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (air quotes) “Lawyer.” You know.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Is...-he in his van now?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Oh... At “van”, her vibe shifts: smirky disdain to curious conc

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's Chris Junior you're talking about. Christian got him that van for his sixteenth if he got all B’s. He flunked but got to keep it anyway. Just sayin’. Ruth processes.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Do you know where your son is now?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Step-son. I have no idea where he is. We haven’t seem him in, jeez, almost a year? He got into drugs, was in jail a little bit, started running around with people he met in there. Creeps. His father finally cut him off, just recently, cancelled his ATM cards, everything. Tough love and whatnot. (dropping her voice) TMI but Chrissy always made me kinda nervous, even before all that. You ever see The Omen?

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The hell is this? CHRIS RUMACK (50s), a WASP God, the race car man from the photo, apparently at the end of an all-night bender, glar unsteadily from the vestibule with CESAR (40s), his flunk with the dead-eyed look of private security.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: The police are asking about Chrissy. Rumack pointedly zips his fly, which was down, and...  64.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: (to Ruth/Tony) That your shitbox out front?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Y-yes, sir, but-- Fast: Cesar draws a GLOCK 9MM from a concealed carry hols and levels it on Ruth and Tony--

dialogues.speaker: HANDS.
dialogues.text: Their hands go up so fast both coffee cups go flying. K-k

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (‘the rug.’ Ohh. Cesar darts forward to quickly pat them both down, and--

dialogues.speaker: DO NOT MOVE.
dialogues.text: --he darts from the room in a tactical crouch as Rumack watches them, nastily amused, polishing his half-tints. Ruth and Tony: both visibly freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Sir-- He puts a finger to his lips. Hush. And she does. He takes a moment, pulls his tie the rest of the way off, rubs his red, puffy eyes, smacks his lips. And finally...

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Meredith. Are you retarded?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare use the R word around me!

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Those are not police.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Then why are you talking to them?  65.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Because I’m fucking borrred!

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Oh shut up, not that again--

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Look at yourself! You’re lucky all we're doing is talking.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Don’t flatter yourself, baby. As Meredith storms out in exasperation--

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I guess I'll just get some soda for the rug.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Clear! Cesar trots back in, his weapon lowered but still in play

dialogues.speaker: CESAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clear. Rumack gestures, lower your hands. They do.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: .»..come home to this shit. Okay. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH TONY
dialogues.text: My name is Ruth. I invoke my Fifth Amendment--

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Your son broke into my house and stole my stuff. From 0.S., Meredith SLAMS cabinets in the kitchen. BAM! B

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK IT OFF.
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (back to Ruth) What’s that got--  66. BAM! He fumes.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s that got to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I thought he lived here.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: So you impersonate cops to...why?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: To find him if he wasn’t here.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: To what end?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: To confront him.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: “How dare you. Wah, wah.” Like that? Ruth’s revulsion at this sarcasm melts through her fear.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yes. Exactly. You can’t do that to people.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: You say that like it means something. Look, I don’t condone my son's behavior but anyone can do anything if you let them. Welcome to the world. You watch the news, don’t you? His words physically rattle her, she has to recover.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No wonder he turned out like he did.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: You have kids? Her non-response is a ‘no.’

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you have no idea what you’re talking about, do you? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christian had more opportunity and assistance than ninety-nine-point-— nine percent of the people on this planet and that’s because of me, of what I did for him, what I provided. If he decides to flush it and live like a degenerate because of mental weakness that’s his choice, he is allowing that to happen just as you allowed yourself to be victimized, but don’t come to me with that nature-nurture horseshit. How much?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: H-how much what? Rumack HURLS his glasses aside--wak!--a sudden micro-tant his temper just as instantly recovered into a shrill grin Ruth and Tony are stunned and... In the now-charged silence, Meredith stomps back in with PAPER TOWELS and SELTZER WATER to sop up the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (muttering) Probably gonna stain. Rumack brings out his WALLET, thumbs the cash inside.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: How much do you want? Staredown: furious Ruth vs. smirking Rumack. Tony’s eyes between them. Meredith ignores it all, working on that st

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t want a payoff.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Then I’m confused. What do you want? She sifts for it, right there on the tip of her tongue:

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: For people...to not...be assholes. Rumack puts the wallet away, now genuinely concerned.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Oh, child...  68. He approaches her, reaches his hand out, and she flinches slightly but allows him to...rest it briefly on her foreh Tony watches. Cesar watches. Even Meredith, now, watches.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACH
dialogues.text: Huh. Thought you might have a fever. And his “concern” morphs back into that nasty grin of condescension. Ruth burns: Fuck. This. Dude.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (to Cesar) Are you going to shoot us? Cesar says nothing. Rumack snorts.

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: Don’t be so goddamned dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Then we’ll leave. She stands, waits for wobbly-kneed Tony, and they head ou

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Meredith) Thank you for the cappuccino. The foam was amazing.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (glumly, without looking) You’re very welcome. Ruth stalks past Rumack, eyes dead ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEADING RUTH AND TONY away, Rumack in the door behind the

dialogues.speaker: RUMACK
dialogues.text: You can tell yourself you’ve done something here, if that’1ll help. Really took a stand. She grinds her jaw, but doesn’t stop, doesn’t turn. And h SLAMS! the door at their backs. TRACKING THEM ACROSS THE HUGE LAWN, passing those ANIMALS Tony trots to keep up.  69.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know what? People like that, that’s just unhappiness eating ‘em up. You oughta feel sorry for him. (when she doesn’t reply) Want me to drive?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Sure. AT RUTH’S CAR, Tony gets behind the wheel but...Ruth stop Something dark churns on her face for a moment and... SHE TURNS AND JOGS BACK ACROSS THE YARD. Her ACTION THEME wails but it’s playing in reverse, distorted and unholy. FROM THE CAR, Tony watches in mounting horror as-- RUTH ATTACKS THE ELEPHANT, savagely trying to uproot it b it’s sturdier than it looks. A wild, grunting frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa whoa! KRAK! RUTH FALLS BACKWARDS, the snapped-off trunk of the elephant in her hands. So she re-doubles and-- ATTACKS THE TIGER INSTEAD, coiling her entire body around ferociously wrenching it loose. SNAP! (And faintly, almos subconsciously, the tiger rawwrs.) FROM THE CAR, Tony watches, aghast as-- RUTH AWKWARDLY SPRINTS BACK, HUGGING THE HUGE TIGER.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under her beath) What are you doing? Why are .-.get the fuck in there... you doing that?! SHE JUMPS IN THE DRIVER’S SIDE, scooting him over to yank gearshift and rev them away, VRRRM! But as they fly out of frame, we drift back to find that. CHRISTIAN’S VAN is parked in the far background, partiall obscured by trees, fifty yards away.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian, Marshall, and Dez watch RUTH’S CAR vanish arou the bend. As her ENGINE fades in the distance, Marshall l sternly to Christian, as if expecting an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: I...I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Cause they were at the place yesterday, too.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: What? No, they weren’t--

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: Yeah, they were. The girl yelled at us. Christian gapes, flummoxed and airless.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: I mean...fuck it, let’s just do it, he’s finally there now--

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (pointing after Ruth) I’m not doing a damn thing until I know what their piece in this is. They’re on us yesterday, they’re here today, she’s obviously nuts, you telling me you’re comfortable with that? We already got the security man to think about. You wanna walk into some kinda dog-fuck n’ take another fall? Cause ol’ Marshall will not be there this time to put a coat on ya, that’s for certain.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. What’m I supposed to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: Ask her. He looks to Marshall, whose blank look co-signs the order it. So Christian pops it into gear...  INT. RUTH’ Who drive 71.

dialogues.speaker: S CAR, (MOVIN)
dialogues.text: in moody silence with the TIGER frozen mid-roar behind them. The silence stretches. Eventually... Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What do you mean, what?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That’s not your lawn tiger.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Did you hear that guy?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I heard him. But he’s not the one that broke into your house and that’s not your lawn tiger. If I'd known that was gonna be the, the, y'know, the objective...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I get it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Of the mission.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I get it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have participated.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I get it. And thanks for the backup in there.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The--? All I’ve done is back you up.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: ‘Til now. He doesn’t know how else to say it, so...  72.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That’s not your lawn tiger. She hasn’t looked at him the whole time and she doesn’t n

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Right. ‘What would Jesus do’, huh? Ouch. He turns away. Moody silence resumes, big time. EXT. STREET - TONY’S HOUSE - DAY RUTH’S CAR pulls over at Tony’s house. Can a car look mor Tony gets out without a word. Ruth watches him go: she’s cooled off and she feels rotten.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Tony... He gives a little forget it wave without looking back and disappears inside. EXT. FRONT YARD - RUTH’S HOUSE - DAY CLOSE ON THE ‘NO DOG SHIT’ SIGN, as RUTH’S CAR jerks to a halt in the out-of-focus background, and out-of-focus Rut then wrestles the TIGER out... She KICKS the sign in anger as she passes it. Thup! INT. FRONT ROOM - RUTH’S HOUSE - DAY THE BAG with the HEAVY PLASTER MOLD drops on the table. T THE TIGER is hurled into the room. Pash! Ruth KICKS IT only to stub the shit out of her toe--wak!

dialogues.speaker: FUCKING. ..THING.
dialogues.text: She flops onto the couch, drops her face into her hands, clutches fistfuls of her hair: some old fashioned seethin In time, she deep-breathes herself out of the red zone an stares out the window a while. What a fucking mess. ALL IN ONE SHOT NOW, she gets up and heads into...  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...with her OPENED FRONT DOOR visible in the background u she veers off to the fridge. Opens it. Gets a beer. Gulping deeply from the can, WE TRACK WITH HER BACK THE W SHE CAME, her FRONT DOOR reappearing in the background an CHRISTIAN is now standing just outside it, this dark background shape she wisps by without noticing and heads

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where she peels out of her sweaty shirt, slips on a fresh one, pauses to gulp more beer. Feeling a little better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes back but pauses suddenly, looking at... THE EMPTY FRONT DOOR which, eerily, is just now shutting last few slow inches on its pneumatic closer. Pssshh-clic She stares at that. Walks towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEADING HER towards the door as she looks out, up and dow the block, but sees nothing. Huh. Weird. BEHIND HER, Christian materializes in the KITCHEN DOORWAY He’s right there, inside the fucking house. That crazy gr Her back is to him, taking a sip as he walks towards her. Twelve feet away. Eight feet. Five feet...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: What’d you tell my Dad? GASP! She WHIRLS at his voice-- HER DROPPED BEER crashes to the floor--KAK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was all maybe three-quarters of a second. Christian staggers, astonished, both hands jerking to his throat wh is making a horrible, reedy, WHISTLING NOISE.  74. Ruth, pulsing with shock and adrenaline, steps aside as-- Christian lurches past her, struggling for air he can’t g giving an almost reproachful look of Why'd you do that? a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --he stumbles outside, heaving and buckling, his FACE QUI TURNING BLUE before our very eyes. Remember Luca Brasi in Godfather? Like that. Nightmare stuff. Ruth steps out after him, stunned into inaction, watching helpless horror as-- Christian staggers down the MIDDLE OF THE ROAD, like he c somehow outrun his own suffocation. Scared to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall and Dez, watching this unfold from a distance--

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Ahh fuck... EXT. STREET - RUTH’S YARD - SAME In his dying panic, Christian has picked up some speed, hobble-lurching towards the INTERSECTION up ahead... His face is PURPLE, clawing his throat, GURGLING pitifull Ruth is at the edge of her yard but still basically froze weakly shaking her head like wait wait wait--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We actually cut away one frame before the moment of impac but IT SOUNDS LIKE A ROAST BEEF DROPPED FROM A SKYSCRAPER At once: Ruth’s SCREAM, the terrible SCREECH of bus brake

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL DEZ
dialogues.text: Hoo boy. Goddamn.  Pink (mm/dd/yyyy) 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RUTH, barely upright under the shock of this moment, digging into her pockets with clumsy hands as, from the O ACCIDENT SCENE, we hear a clamor of SCREAMS...

dialogues.speaker: / --RAN OUT IN FRONTA ME
dialogues.text: She gets her PHONE out, trying to remember how to work it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerking it into gear--

dialogues.speaker: DEZ MARSHALL
dialogues.text: She's calling, she’s calling-- I see it, I see it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth turns away from the CHAOS DOWN THE STREET, gulping f breath, the PHONE to her ear-- PHONE V.O. 911 operator, what is your emergency?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Uhhhhhhhh. PHONE V.O. Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He just, he was just, he he he-- There’s a NEW SCREECH of tires, very close behind her, an

dialogues.speaker: DEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can help you, honey. Ruth turns around just in time to see-- DEZ SWINGING THE BUTT OF A SHOTGUN AT HER FACE. KRAK. CUT TO BLACK.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACKNESS. Occasionally penetrated by SMEARS OF LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She mighta said our names.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She doesn't know ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She knew Chrissy's alright.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We oughta kill her anyway, then.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ask her when she wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, she's awake now. CLOSE ON RUTH, jouncing on the floor of the van, a SWOLLE GASH above her eye. Stripes of SUNLIGHT wipe her face, rhythmically. She’s terrified. She squirms but... HER WRISTS are bound with duct tape. Painfully, she cranes her neck around to see-- MARSHALL AND DEZ: THEIR HEADS MADE OUT OF CLOTH. Homemade masks, t-shirts with eyeholes. Creeeeepy. Marshall drives. Dez stares back at her, holding her PHON

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: What’d you tell ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know who you are. Dez chucks the phone out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: How'd you find Chrissy?  77.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: C-computer.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: And what? You just went after him on your own?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I tried to tell the cops. Before. But they didn’t listen. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: What about his dad?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He didn’t care either! Dez stares at her, like trying to see inside her brain.

dialogues.speaker: DEZ
dialogues.text: (to Marshall) Whatcha think?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
